The objectives of the Requirements Management phase are to:

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the Architecture Requirements Specification?

discussion.content:
Yes.
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap32.html#tag_32_02_06

The Architecture Requirements Specification provides a set of quantitative statements that outline what an implementation project must do in order to comply with the architecture. An Architecture Requirements Specification will typically form a major component of an implementation contract or contract for a more detailed Architecture Definition.

Typical contents of an Architecture Requirements Specification are:
■ Success measures
■ Architecture requirements
■ Business service contracts
■ Application service contracts
■ Implementation guidelines
■ Implementation specifications
■ Implementation standards
■ Interoperability requirements
■ IT Service Management requirements
■ Constraints
■ Assumptions

The Architecture Definition Document provides a qualitative view of the solution and aims to communicate the intent of the architect. The Architecture Requirements Specification provides a quantitative view of the solution, stating measurable criteria that must be met during the implementation of the architecture.

20.4.1 Qualities of Principles
1. *Understandability* - clear and well understood.
2. *Robustness* - Should be definitive and precise to enable good quality decisions.
3. *Completeness* - The principles cover every situation perceived and all important principles are defined.
4. *Consistency* - The set of principles must be expressed in a way that allows a balance
of interpretations. Principles should not be contradictory each other.
5. *Stability* - Principles should be solid, but able to accommodate changes.

■ Complete: every potentially important principle governing the management of
information and technology for the organization is defined — the principles cover every

questions.question_text: What is part of the approach in the ADM Preliminary Phase?

discussion.content:
This Preliminary Phase is about defining "where, what, why, who, and how we do architecture" in the enterprise concerned. The main aspects are as follows:

1) Defining the enterprise.
2) Identifying key drivers and elements in the organizational context.
3) Defining the requirements for architecture work.
4) Defining the Architecture Principles that will inform any architecture work.
5) Defining the framework to be used.
6) Defining the relationships between management frameworks.
7) Evaluating the Enterprise Architecture maturity.
